fields.name: History
fields.history:
Welcome to Cameroon Protestant College, (C.P.C.) Bali, a trail blazer and a cradle for solid general Education since A.D. 1949.

Cameroon Protestant College, (C.P.C.) Bali is a jealously guarded boarding nursery and mould for the cream of modern Cameroon's Who is Who.

This citadel of learning is situated in the outskirts of Bamenda town, the capital of the North West Region of Cameroon.

With her Motto: “God, Knowledge, Service”, the school, run by the Presbyterian church in Cameroon, the (P.C.C.) and functioning in the Department of the Presbyterian Education Authority the (P.E.A) offers holistic general Education at the First and Second cycles of the Anglo-Saxon system of education.

Cameroon Protestant College, 9C.P.C.) Bali the formidable path-finder in education was planted in Bali by the Germans and the Swiss in 1949, making her the oldest Protestant and Presbyterian college in the North West Region.

Since then, the school has consciously followed the Protestant flare for precision, fanaticism for details and strengths and prowess in Christian education and moral rectitude. A blend of these attributes give a lasting solution to knowledge seekers.

When curtains of Cameroon Protestant college (C.P.C.) Bali, were raised, admission was reserved for boys only, but as time evolved, the school dynamically embraced girls in 1972, giving her a gender balanced status.

Although Cameroon Protestant college (C.P.C.) Bali follows the English speaking systems of education, she opens her doors to learners from all the regions of Cameroon and even beyond, who can adequately fit in and cope with the culture of the institution.

The medium of instructions in Cameroon Protestant college, (C.P.C.) Bali is English Language, while French and English Languages are the authorized languages spoken in the school community.

Cameroon Protestant college, (C.P.C.) Bali fondly called “Bali College”, or “CAMPROCOL”, dedicates herself to the continuous quest for academic excellence and moral values necessary in child upbringing. She seeks to prepare progressive young boys and girls to confidently and vibrantly embrace the future with fortitude, intelligence and Godliness.

Multitudes of students come to Cameroon Protestant college (C.P.C.) Bali with their empty vessels ready to fetch and they happily make their exit with their vessels full to the brim with morality, knowledge and discipline. Overwhelmed with their harvest under the foot of the accommodating “Matterhorn”, they hurry out there to take their places in the Prestigious Second to none alumni “BOBA”.

The school for over decades has experienced a steady rise in enrolment and staff strength. In the 2014/2015 academic year, it hit the bar with 1016 students.

Infrastructurally, the Bali College of recent years has a new look with newly constructed lanes with refurbished structures and with the beautifully pruned lawns and flowers exhibiting an environmental touch, the view is more than attractive.

Personnel and students take their turns in the Cameroon Protestant college, (C.P.C.) Bali, but the college keeps growing by leaps and bounds, earning the pride of place both nationally and internationally and forever remains an icon of the Presbyterian Education Authority (P.E.A.).

For more information about “CAMPROCOL”, you are invited to log in and enjoy a rich menu. For more, contact the Principal on: Telephone 77519215 and email Wilsonkamayoh@yahoo.com.

fields.name: Time Log
fields.history:
A Look at the College Log Book

1947- Idea for creation of Basel Mission College concieved in Basel.

1948- Discusses in Cameroon. Common exam was conducted in September. In all there were 130 candidiates.

Jan. 1949- Mr, .P. Schneider and Mr.J.A. Ozimba recieved some boys into the dormitories before the end of January at the old sire situated behind the present Fon's palace. There were 53 boys, but five more came late. The fees were /-12 per annum.

Feb. 2, 1949- The Principal, Mr. D.H. O'Neill, B.A., arrived at Bali from the United Kingdom. He was formally installed and the College declared open at 4:30pm by the Rev.A.Augst, acting for Rev.F.Raaflaub, on behalf of the Basel Mission. The staff at this date was as follows:

Mr. D.H. O'Neill, Principal

Mr. Jean Pierre Schneider

Mr. J.A. Ozimba

Feb. 23, 1949- Rev. Dr.F.Raaflaub, Secretary and Supervisor of the Basel Mission visited the school and addressed the students. On the same day, Hon. Mang Williams, Member of the Eastern House of Assembly also paid the college a visit.

April 6/7, 1949- <<Sorting-out>> examination was conducted to separate boys into Classes one and two. Twenty-eight were allowed to sit back Class one.

May 17, 1949- Rev. J. Grest and Mr. P. Keller of Basel Mission met with Bali Town Council members and marked boundaries of the sight for the new college buildings.

June 1, 1949- College library was opened to the boys for them to borrow books. About 80 books were available.

Nov. 26, 1949- First meeting of College Board of Governors held in the Principal's home. It was attended by Re. Dr. F. Raaflaub, Rev. J. Grest, Rev. W. Zürcher, Mr. E. A. Ekiti, Mr. P. P. Grey the District Officer, Mr. W. H. P. Browne the Provincial Education Officer, The Fon of Bali, Hish Highness Galega II and Mr. Maxwell Fohtung.

Mar. 28, 1950- There were no classes. The students marched to the new site where foundation stomes for the new school building were laid by His Honour, the Resident of Bamenda Province, W.B. Spencer, Esq., and by the Rev. Inspector N. Witschi of Basel, Switzerland.

Feb. 22, 1951- The Resident of Bamenda Province, Mr.F.R. Kat, visited the college. After inspecting the classes, he addressed the bots and staff of the constitution for Bigeria and the elctions to be held shortly.

Mar. 4/5, 1952- Principal's house used as Head Quarters pf Province by Resident during the Bali/Widikum war.

July 3, 1952- A grant of /1000 was recieved from the Director of Education, Enugu, for the science building.

Sept. 23, 1952- A staff meeting recommended to the Board of Governors that Latin be dropped from the curriculum and French and Science be begun in class one.

Jan. 21, 19540 H.N. Agbor and W.M. Mfone, the first Old boys, joined the staff.

Mar. 13, 1954- The First results of <<Cantab>> released. 10 out of 20 boys passed, with 2 in Grade I, 4 in Grade II, and 12 in Grade III.

April 4, 1956- Visit of His Excellency Sir Jamed Robertson, Governor General of the Federation of Nigeria, with Lady Robertson and Miss C. Robertson. They had tea and inspected the college informally.

April 22, 1956- The Principal, Mr.Walters and Mr.Capill met with ten old boys of the college at Buea and discussed the formation of an Old Boys Association.

June 6, 1956- Mr. Capill left for Buea for meeting of Basel Mission with Baptist Mission to discuss co-operation in running the college.

June 13, 1956- Mr. Capill returned from Buea. Word was received that under the new arrangements, the college is to be called 'Cameroons Union College' and that Rev. H. Giger, now of Nyasoso, has been appointed as the new Principal to take up duties next June.

June 17, 1957- Mr.Dudley R. Reeves introduced by Rev. Ben Lawrence as the first expatraite member of staff supplied by the Cameroon Baptist Mission. Mr. D. Nsame was the first Baptist African staff.

Aug. 18, 1957- In the afternoon a function was held at Mr. Fohtung's house, given by the Town Council of Bali under the chairmanship of the Fon of Bali, to honour the ourgoing Principal, Mr. D.H. O'Neill. The entire college staff attended this function. Later a report appeared in the “Daily Times”. Rev. H. Giger takes over the administration of the college.

Oct. 8, 1957- Under this date, the Supervisor of Schools, Basel Mission, Buea, informs me that L.E.O. Has approved the new constitution of the college and that it is therefore now in force. The college is now an affair of the Basel Mission and the Cameroon Baptist Mission. The name of the college is henceworth Cameroon Protestant College, Bale.

Jan. 26, 1959- Dr. P. Rudin became Ag. Principal.

Jan. 27, 1959- Electric plant arrived.

Jan. 6, 1960- Mr. Haupr became Ag. Zprincipal.

Each student received a copy of the constiution of the Federal Rebuplic of Cameroon.

Oct. 1, 1961- Independance Day. Hoisted the new flad, sand the national anthem in French and English, had common meal and native dances.

Oxt. 25, 1961- Mr. D. Witt takes over, as Vice Principal, responsiblity for the College.

Jan. 25, 1962- Mr. B. Muluh, Grade !! Techer, College leaver of 1954, who previously worked with CDC, joins the staff.

Mar 28, 1962-- The President, His Excellency, Mr. Ahidjo, is welcomes by the whole of the student body and staff on Bali Airstrip. In the afternoon students were allowed to inspect the plane.

Sept. 10, 1962- Four Peace Crops arrives: Miss B. Wollozin, Miss G. Vinson, Messrs. Carlson and Don. Graduation Year of the first double stream catch.

Feb. 8, 1963- Application to London University to be approved as a centre for G.C'.E. 'O' Level.

Dec. 14, 1964- The college welcomes Mrs. Ahidjo at the airstrip.

July 18, 1966- Mr. J.A. Ozimba, Senior Tutor, leaves the college to become Supervisor of Grassfield Schools. He has been on the staff, with interruptions, since the beginning of the college on 2nd February 1949.

Sept. 30, 1966- Miss Esther Schaetti of the Bsel Mission, from Switzerland, arrives as a tutor for French & Biology ater service in Ghana for several years.

April 1, 1967- Mr. Louis Van Eerten is Principal of the college.

1968- Federal Minister of Education, Yaoundé, visits the college and supports the extension of the college to include Advanced level work.

April 1, 1969- Mr. L. Van Eerten hands over the Principalship of the college to Rev. Martin Schurian.

Oct. 8/9, 1969- Strike of the students. Senior Divisional Officer, Bamenda, is called and students go back to work in the afternoon. The Food Master, Mr. Sayani, is relieved after investigations, from his duties as Food Master.

Dec. 13, 1969- Rev. Schurian goes to Buea to prepare the final application for development funds for the extension of the college to Form VI from the Dutch Government.

June 19, 1970- Send-off for Rev. Gordon in the Assembly Hall; speeches by various old boys. He has served for 10 years.

May10, 1971- Handing over of office from Rev. Martin Schurian to Rev. Martin Wyss.

Dec. 26, 1971- Mr. S.N. Mfonyam takes over full responsibility for the college as Principal.

March 14, 1972- Foundation Day of CPC observed, Old boys of CPC were conspicuously represented. Noteworthy is the fact that the Bali Old Boys Association (BOBA) donated generously towards the extension programme of CPC; through its [president, Mr. M.T. Munji, the Principal thus received a cheque of 150.000 francs on behalf of the school, with deep appreciation.

May 20, 1972- Referendum Day, The school vehicle was used throughout the day for supervising Polling Stations at the request of the S.D.O. The Principal and the Vice-Principal were Returning Officers.

Oct. 5, 1972- Commencement day of the CPC Higher School (Sixth Form) Section. The first batch of students, boys and girls arrived CPC campus for orientation. Mr. H.L. Stapper arrived late in the evening from home (Holland) to take up his appointment as tutor in CPC.

Jan. 19, 1973- Principal announces with deep regret the death of Mr. D.H. O'Neill, the first Principal of CPC (then, in 1949, Basel Mission College). He died on the 11th October 1972, in Nigeria where he was working. Since the announcement was made during morning devotion, the college observed a minute's silence in memory of the late Mr. O'Neill.

Feb. 12, 1973- The college football team had a replay of the O.S.U.S.C. finals with L.C.C. at the Mankon Stadium. The game ended in favour of CPC; scores were CPC 1, L.C.C. 0.

April 22, 1973- The late Mr. D.H. O'Neill's Memorial Service held in the College chapel with many Old Boys in attendance.

Feb. 16, 1974- CPC wins O.S.U.S.C. Football finals against Agricultural School, Bambili.

March 17, 1974- Silver Jubilee Planning Committee met in Mankon in 1958 Club.

 

S.B. Arrey-Mbi

1961-1965
